ุฅูู ุฅูู.

ูฃูกูกโูฃูขูคุ ูขูููฆ. 

(ูจ-ูข) ุฅูุฏุงุก ูู ุฒููุง ุฏูุฑูุชุณููุ ูุคุณุณุฉ ุงูุนููู ุงููุทููุฉุ ุฃุฑูููุฌุชููุ ููุฑุฌูููุงุ ุงูููุงูุงุช ุงููุชุญุฏุฉ ุงูุฃูุฑูููุฉ. 

(ูฉ-ูก) ูู ุงูุจุฑูุงูุฌ ุงูุชุนูููู ูููููุฉ ุงูุฃูุฑูููุฉ ูุนูู ุงูุฃุดุนุฉ (ุงูุฅุตุฏุงุฑ ุงูุซุงูู ููุณู ุนูู ุงูุฃุดุนุฉ ุงูุนุตุจูุฉ)ุ ุญููู ุงููุดุฑ ูุญููุธุฉ ูุนุงู ูขูููค. 
ุฃูุนููุฏู ูุดุฑ ุงูุตูุฑุฉ ุจุชุตุฑูุญ ูู ุงููููุฉ ุงูุฃูุฑูููุฉ ูุนูู ุงูุฃุดุนุฉ. ูุง ููุตุฑููุญ ุจูุดุฑ ุฃู ูุณุฎ ุฃุฎุฑู ูู ูุฐู ุงููุงุฏุฉ ุฏูู ุฅุฐูู ุฎุทููู ุตุฑูุญ ูู ุงููููุฉ 
ุงูุฃูุฑูููุฉ ูุนูู ุงูุฃุดุนุฉ. 

(ูฉ-ูข) ููุดูุฑูุช ุงูุตูุฑุฉ ุจุชุตุฑูุญ ูู ูุงูุฏุฉ ููููุ ููู ุชุฑูุณ. 

[1mุซุจุช ุงููุฑุงุฌุน [0m

I have written [3mLife Ascending [0mmostly from primary sources, but the books highlighted below were all sources of insight and 
enjoyment for me. I donโt agree with everything in all of them, but that is part of the pleasure of a good book. Most are written 
for the general reader and are original scientific works in the tradition of [3mThe Origin of Species [0mitself. Alphabetical order. 

David Beerling [3mThe Emerald Planet [0m(OUP, 2006). A splendid book on the impact of plants on the history of our planet. Colourful 
extended vignettes of evolution. 

Susan Blackmore [3mConversations on Consciousness [0m(OUP, 2005). An admirably level-headed attempt to canvas and make sense of the 
conflicting views of leading scientists and philosophers on consciousness. 

Jacob Bronowski [3mThe Ascent of Man [0m(Little, Brown, 1974). The book of the TV series. Magnificent. 

Graham Cairns-Smith [3mSeven Clues to the Origin of Life [0m(CUP, 1982). Scientifically an old book now, but unequalled for its Sherlock 
Holmesian. examination of the clues at the heart of lifeโs chemistry. 

โโโ, [3mEvolving the Mind [0m(CUP, 1998). An excellent and unusual defence of quantum theories of consciousness from a determinedly 
individual thinker. 

Francis Crick [3mLife Itself [0m(Simon & Schuster, 1981). An indefensible hypothesis defended by one of the finest scientific minds of 
the twentieth century. Dated, but still worth a read. 

Antonio Damasio [3mThe Feeling of What Happens [0m(Vintage Books, 2000). One of several books by Damasio, all well worth a read. Poetic 
and intense; at its best on neurology, and weakest on evolution.. 

Charles Darwin [3mThe Origin of Species [0m(Penguin, 1985). Among the most important books ever written. 

Paul Davies [3mThe Origin of Life [0m. (Penguin, 2006). A fine book, if perhaps prone to see too many obstacles. 

Richard Dawkins [3mClimbing Mount Improbable [0m(Viking, 1996). One of surprisingly few popular books to deal explicitly with the 
evolution of complex traits like eyes, in Dawkinsโ inimitable style. 

โโโ, [3mThe Selfish Gene [0m(OUP, 1976). One of the defining books of our age. A must-read. 

Daniel Dennett [3mConsciousness Explained [0m(Little, Brown, 1991). A controversial classic that canโt be ignored. 

Derek Denton [3mThe Primordial Emotions [0m(OUP, 2005). An eloquent book with an important thesis, all the better for its excellent 
discussions of the work of other researchers and philosophers. 

Christian de Duve [3mSingularities [0m(CUP, 2005). A densely argued book, encapsulating much of de Duveโs clear thinking. Not for the 
chemically faint-hearted, but the distillations of a fine mind. 

โโโ, [3mLife Evolving [0m(OUP, 2002). An elegiac book on the biochemical evolution of life and our place in the universe. It reads like 
a swan song, but in fact precedes [3mSingularities [0m. 

Gerald Edelman [3mWider than the Sky [0m(Penguin, 2004). A slim but dense volume, and a good introduction to Edelmanโs important ideas. 

Richard Fortey [3mTrilobite! [0m(HarperCollins 2000). A delight, as are all Forteyโs books, and especially good on the evolution of the 
trilobitesโ crystal eye. 

Tibor Ganti [3mThe Principles of Life [0m(OUP, 2003). An original take on the fundamental make-up of life, if lacking in real-world 
biochemistry. I reluctantly did not discuss his ideas. 

Steven Jay Gould [3mThe Structure of Evolutionary Theory [0m(Harvard University Press, 2002). A serious work of scholarship, but with 
flashes of Gouldโs customary panache; a goldmine of interesting material. 

Franklin Harold [3mThe Way of the Cell [0m(OUP, 2001). A wonderful, insightful book on the cell, full of the poetry of deep science. Not 
always easy but well worth the effort. 

Steve Jones [3mThe Language of the Genes [0m(Flamingo, 2000). Wonderful introduction to the gene; effervescent. 

โโโ, [3mAlmost like a Whale [0m(Doubleday, 1999). Darwin updated with panache and deep learning. 

Horace Freeland Judson [3mThe Eighth Day of Creation [0m(Cold Spring Harbor Press, 1996). A seminal tome: interviews with the pioneers 
of molecular biology, at the dawn of an era. 

Tom Kirkwood [3mTime of Our Lives [0m(Weidenfeld & Nicolson, 1999). One of the best introductions to the biology of ageing, by a pioneer 
in the field; a humane work of science. 

Andre Klarsfeld and Frederic Revah [3mThe Biology of Death [0m(Cornell University Press, 2004). A thoughtful examination of aging and 
death, from the point of view of the cell. A rare meld of evolution and medicine. 

Andrew Knoll [3mLife on a Young Planet [0m(Princeton University Press, 2003). A fine, accessible view of early evolution by one of the 
leading protagonists. Wise counsel. 

Christof Koch [3mThe Quest for Consciousness [0m(Roberts & Co, 2004). A textbook, and not an easy read, but full of flair and insight. A 
fine and balanced mind enquiring into the mind. 

Marek Kohn [3mA Reason for Everything [0m(Faber and Faber, 2004). Short biographies of five British evolutionists, full of eloquence and 
insight. Very good on the evolution of sex. 

Michael Land and Dan-Eric Nilsson [3mAnimal Eyes [0m(OUP, Oxford, 2002). A textbook on animal optics, accessibly written and conveying 
well the exuberant ingenuity of evolution. 

Nick Lane [3mPower, Sex, Suicide [0m(OUP, 2005). My own exploration of cell biology and the evolution of complexity, from the point of 
view of cellular energy. 

โโโ, [3mOxygen [0m(OUP, 2002). A history of life on earth with the gas that made complex life possible, oxygen, taking centre-stage. 

Primo Levi [3mThe Periodic Table [0m(Penguin, 1988). Not really a science book at all, but brimming with poetry, humanity and science. A 
master literary craftsman. 

Lynn Margulis and Dorion Sagan [3mMicrocosmos [0m(University of California Press, 1997). A fine introduction to the grand scale of the 
microcosm from one of the iconic figures in biology, no stranger to controversy. 

Bill Martin and Miklรณs Mรผller [3mOrigin of Mitochondria and Hydrogenosomes [0m(Springer, 2007). A scholarly multi-author text on a 
seminal event in evolution: disparate views of the eukaryotic cell. 

John Maynard Smith and Eรถrs Szathmรกry [3mThe Origins of Life [0m(OUP, 1999). A popular reworking of their classic text [3mThe Major 
Transitions in Evolution [0m(WH Freeman/Spektrum, 1995). A major work by great intellects. 

John Maynard Smith [3mDid Darwin get it Right? [0m(Penguin, 1988). Accessible essays, some on the evolution of sex, by the late guru of 
evolutionary biologists. 

Oliver Morton [3mEating the Sun [0m(Fourth Estate, 2007). A gem of a book, combining a novelistโs insight into people and place with a 
deep feeling for molecules and planets. Especially good on the carbon crisis. 

Andrew Parker [3mIn the Blink of an Eye [0m(Free Press, 2003). Much to savour, despite a rather blinkered view. 

Vilayanur Ramachandran [3mThe Emerging Mind [0m(Profile, 2003). Ramachandranโs 2003 Reith lectures, essentially his earlier book [3m
Phantoms in the Brain [0min compressed form. An original and imaginative mind at play. 

Mark Ridley [3mMendelโs Demon [0m(Weidenfeld & Nicolson, 2000). An intellectual treat, lacing its profound material on the evolution of 
complexity with grave wit. 

Matt Ridley [3mThe Red Queen [0m(Penguin, 1993). A seminal book on the evolution of sex and sexual behaviour; insightful and full of 
Ridleyโs trademark flair. 

โโโ, [3mFrancis Crick [0m(HarperPress, 2006). A first-rate biography of one of the most interesting figures in twentieth century 
science. Nicely nuanced, without ever jeopardising his love of the subject. 

Steven Rose [3mThe Making of Memory [0m(Vintage 2003). A fine book on the neural events underlying memory, at its best on the social 
framework of science. 

Ian Stewart and Jack Cohen [3mFigments of Reality [0m(CUP, 1997). An eclectic, witty and erudite look at consciousness. Entertaining and 
opinionated. 

Peter Ward [3mOut of Thin Air [0m(Joseph Henry Press, 2006). A serious and original hypothesis about why dinosaurs were dominant for so 
long. Accessible and compelling. 

Carl Zimmer [3mParasite Rex [0m(The Free Press, 2000). A superb book on the importance of parasites, with an excellent section on the 
role of parasites in the evolution of sex. 

[1mุงููุตุงุฏุฑ ุงูุฑุฆูุณูุฉ [0m

Francis Crick once complained that โThere is no form of prose more difficult to understand and more tedious to read than the 
average scientific paperโ. He had a pointโbut he did use the word โaverageโ. At their best, scientific papers can be pure 
distillations of meaning, and capable of exercising as much pull on the mind as a work of art. I have tried to limit my list here 
to papers of that calibre: this is not an exhaustive list, but a selection of the papers that most influenced my thinking in 
writing this book. Iโve also added a few general reviews as entrรฉes into the literature. Alphabetical order by chapter. 

[1mููุฏูุฉ [0m

Russell R. J., Gerike U., Danson M. J., Hough D. W., Taylor G. L. Structural adaptations of the cold-active citrate synthase from 
an Antarctic bacterium. [3mStructure [0m6: 351โ61; 1998.
